Key Match Events: West Indies lost to England by 8 wickets
Brandon King was forced to retire hurt with a side strain in the fifth over
Phil Salt clobbered Roston Shepherd for three 6s and three 4s in the 16th over
Post-Match Reflections: Rovman Powell expressed hope that King can ‘pull through’ to face USA and South Africa
Jonny Bairstow was praised for his mature, senior player’s innings
Miscellaneous Highlights: The result means that West Indies’ next outing against co-hosts, United States, at Kensington Oval on Friday night will be a do or die affair
West Indies must win against USA and South Africa, on Sunday, to keep their dreams of a third T20 World Cup title alive
Others: England scored 58 from the powerplay, while West Indies were not exactly free-flowing with the bat either
West Indies’ problems started when they were inserted to bat, though. They were 40 without loss when opener Brandon King was forced to retire hurt with a side strain in the fifth over
At 54-0 at the end of the powerplay, Powell would have hoped to get to 200 runs again—as they did against Afghanistan at the same ground on Monday
Johnson Charles, Nicholas Pooran and Powell failed to build on starts and all perished in their 30s, as the West Indies tallied 51 dot balls

And West Indies were 143 for 4 at the start of the 18th over, with Sherfane Rutherford on 1 and Shepherd 0. The pair contributed a valuable 37-run partnership, with Rutherford getting 27 of those runs
England, who scored 58 from the powerplay, were not exactly free-flowing with the bat either. But they managed the game well and benefitted from a 97-run partnership by Salt and Jonny Bairstow
